ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ASIA PACIFIC ECONOMIC COOPERATION (APEC) MEETING IN AUCKLAND

(Update)


    1. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Prime Minister (a) whether he will give an update on the recent Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) meeting in Auckland, New Zealand, and in particular elaborate on the idea of signing Free Trade Agreements (FTAs) with other countries, and (b) how such FTAs would impact the trade agreements within ASEAN.

    The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, from Singapore's perspective, the outcome of the Auckland APEC meeting was positive. There was strong support for the launch of a New Round of multilateral trade negotiations, which would help lower market access barriers for Singapore's goods and services. There was also agreement on the scope and modalities of such negotiations. These are strong messages which would give significant impetus to efforts to launch a New Round at the Third WTO Ministerial Conference later this year at Seattle, as APEC economies account for more than half the global trade.

Column: 279



    New Zealand has ably and skilfully chaired APEC this year towards these strong outcomes. It has managed well the bilateral and sub-regional side issues that had threatened to overshadow the APEC meetings. The general consensus is that New Zealand has put APEC back on track, and restored a good measure of the grouping's relevance and credibility.

    At the fringes of the Auckland APEC meetings, Singapore announced that we would be entering into Free Trade Agreement (FTA) negotiations with New Zealand. We also reached an agreement with Mexico to explore the possibility of a bilateral FTA, and with Chile and New Zealand for a study on a 3-party FTA.

    Let me put these FTA initiatives in perspective. While we pursue FTAs with strategic partners, our primary emphasis is still the multilateral trading system represented by the WTO. The WTO is the only institution that can ensure a fair and predictable environment for global trade. This is particularly important for a small country heavily dependent on trade like Singapore. We would be much poorer off in a world where trade is not governed by international rules and dominated instead by individual economies or regional blocs.

    The objective of our FTA with New Zealand and others is to use them as catalysts to accelerate the pace of trade liberalisation within APEC. In 1994, APEC Leaders at Bogor made a commitment to achieve free and open trade and investment by 2010 for developed economies and by 2020 for developing economies. We think that one way to fast-track the achievement of the Bogor vision is through sub-APEC FTAs. APEC economies which are ready to embrace the Bogor goals of free trade earlier should be encouraged to form FTAs among themselves. Our FTA with New Zealand will be grounded on Bogor goals and will be open to participation by other economies. In this way, we see the Singapore-New Zealand FTA as being a stepping stone towards an eventual APEC-wide FTA, thus realising the Bogor vision.

Column: 280



    At Auckland, we were pleasantly surprised to note that several other APEC leaders shared a similar view. They are discussing FTAs among themselves, for example, Korea and Chile, Japan and Mexico.

    Singapore remains committed to ASEAN and the establishment of a strong ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA) that is attractive to investors. This is in our own interest because our long-term fortunes are inextricably tied to ASEAN. Our FTA initiatives will not detract from our commitments and obligations in ASEAN. We will continue to work hard for the implementation of the AFTA Agreement, the ASEAN Agreement on Services, the ASEAN Investment Area and other ASEAN economic initiatives.

    Our decision to enter into FTAs with other trading partners can help to strengthen the region. We see the Singapore-New Zealand FTA as a preliminary step to build up linkages between ASEAN and other regions, for example, the Closer Economic Relations (CER) grouping of Australia and New Zealand. At a recent ASEAN meeting with Australia and New Zealand, the Ministers agreed to set up a high level taskforce to study the feasibility of establishing an FTA between ASEAN and the CER by the year 2010. This will strengthen ASEAN's negotiating position in the global trading system.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether the Government has plans to also extend these FTAs with other countries, besides New Zealand, Mexico and Chile.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: We have had preliminary discussions with the United States, Australia, New Zealand and Chile on the possibility of a P5 arrangement to liberalise trade among ourselves. And with some other countries, we have also initiated preliminary discussions.

    Mr Simon S C Tay (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, may I ask the Minister, given the trade increases within Asia itself, would the Government

Column: 281

consider prioritising a Free Trade Agreement with Japan or other East Asian economies?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Our offer is to all those who are ready to move along with us. We have little difficulty in establishing FTAs with other countries. So those countries that are prepared to move earlier than others, we will welcome them to join us. For this reason, our FTA negotiations with New Zealand are based upon open-ended membership.

    Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker, how far would the FTA between New Zealand and Singapore go? Will it also include travel between the citizens of the two countries?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: There is already free travel between the peoples of the two countries. I do not think we require visas to visit each other. I wonder whether this is the question which Mr Chiam is posing to me or he is referring to something else.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: Free travel, like in Europe between the countries which have a free trade area.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: I do not think that we will agree on the free migration of people without control, which is possible in Europe now.

    Dr Tan Boon Wan (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether, in view of the fact that there is an economic crisis, there will be a delay in achieving the Bogor time limit of 2010/2020 for the liberalisation of tariffs.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, two weeks ago, I chaired the ASEAN meeting in Singapore. Before the meeting, I did not have very high expectations because we are just coming out of the economic crisis and I thought that many other member countries would rather concentrate on their own domestic problems first before looking at regional issues. But to my pleasant surprise, the mood was very positive and there was strong determination to carry forward

Column: 282

with initiatives like the ASEAN Free Trade Area and the ASEAN Investment Area, and which was why it was possible for us to talk about something which we had not talked about before, which was the possibility of establishing an FTA between ASEAN and the CER.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee: I would like to ask the Minister whether there is a possibility of a Free Trade Agreement with China.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Sir, China of course represents the greatest Free Trade Area in the world with 1.2 billion people. I do not think it is in China's interest for the time being to enter into an FTA with us. It will of course be in our interest to enter into an FTA with China. As I said earlier, our offer is to everyone in APEC and that includes China.

Column: 282

STAMP DUTY ON PROPERTY TRANSACTIONS


    2. Dr Wang Kai Yuen asked the Minister for Finance, having brought forward the payment due date of the stamp duty on property transactions as part of the package to deter real-estate speculation, (a) how many of these transactions have failed to complete after the stamp duty has been paid; (b) whether it is equitable for a purchaser to bear the stamp duty of an incomplete transaction resulting from circumstances beyond his reasonable control and (c) will the Government review the procedure to minimize this unnecessary burden on such a purchaser.

    The Second Minister for Finance (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no requirement for failed transactions to be reported to IRAS. IRAS therefore does not have information on the number of failed transactions.

    The Stamp Duties Act was recently amended to allow refund in the following circumstances:

    (i) the vendor is unable to prove his title to the property;

Column: 283



    (ii) a purchaser, being a foreign person, is unable to obtain approval under the Residential Property Act (Chapter 274) to acquire or purchase the property;

    (iii) the property is acquired or is proposed for acquisition by any public authority pursuant to the provisions of any written law authorising or empowering the public authority to acquire land compulsorily;

    (iv) the purchase of the property is conditional upon permission by the competent authority to develop or subdivide the property and such permission is refused;

    (v) either vendor or purchaser fails to obtain the approval of any public authority to sell or purchase, as the case may be, the property;

    (vi) the Commissioner of Building Control makes an order under section 24 of the Building Control Act in respect of the property, ie, the building is unfit for occupation; or

    (vii) a Strata Titles Board refuses an application for the sale of the property under section 84A, 84D or 84E of the Land Titles (Strata) Act (Chapter 158), ie, rejection of an application for en-bloc sale.

    If the purchaser aborts the transaction, then the stamp duty is part of the cost for aborting the transaction. This is the intent of bringing forward the payment of the date of the stamp duty. If the seller aborts the transaction, then the purchaser should take legal action to enforce the contract. Nevertheless, stamp duty has been waived on a case by case basis where the purchaser has been able to offer satisfactory evidence that the transaction was aborted due to circumstances beyond his control and was not a speculative venture.

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether it would be more logical to revert to the original system of collecting stamp duty, in other words, at the completion of the transaction. Some of the letters and responses that I have received from IRAS

Column: 284

to my constituents state that stamp duty is a processing fee. As such, regardless of whether a transaction is completed or not, it is collectable. If the fee is such a big amount and dependent on the value of the transaction, surely it is not processing fee.

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, if the Member can remember, we brought forward the payment of the stamp duty in 1996, as part of the anti-speculation measures. That was the whole idea - to bring forward the payment of the stamp duty so that only bona fide purchasers, who have real intent to buy property, will go into a transaction and they pay the cost. This is to deter speculation.

    In the past, when stamp duty was paid at the end of the transaction, it did not cost very much for somebody to take out an option, speculate on a property, and if the market takes a downturn, abort the transaction. So this measure of bringing it forward is part and parcel of the anti-speculation package in 1996.

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen: Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether the Government had thought through the consequences of bringing forward the payment of the stamp duty. Because in the past, the fee was only paid upon completion of the transaction. Based on the reason that he outlined, for bona fide buyers who cannot complete the transaction for whatever reason, they are still obligated to pay the stamp duty, and that is surely not the intent of the anti-speculation measures.

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, I have already explained the reason for bringing forward the payment. Yes, of course, the Government thought through the whole issue before announcing the package in 1996.

    If the transaction did not go through because of circumstances beyond the purchaser's control, as I have explained earlier of the seven circumstances, due to reason of the purchaser not being able to get the necessary approval to complete the transaction, then the stamp duty will be refunded. If the transaction fails to go through because the seller aborts the transaction, then the purchaser is entirely

Column: 285

within his rights to enforce the contract. If the purchaser himself aborts the transaction, then it is part and parcel of the cost. He knows, before he enters into a transaction, that if he fails to go through with the transaction and he aborts the transaction, then this is part and parcel of the cost involved in aborting the transaction.

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen: Sir, if I come across cases where the transaction cannot be completed because of circumstances beyond the control of the buyer, can I bring the cases to him for favourable review, and have the stamp duty refunded?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: As I have mentioned, we do consider this on a case-by-case basis. But we need very good evidence that the transaction is aborted beyond the control of the purchaser. If the purchaser aborts the transaction, you cannot say that that is beyond his control, because he himself aborted the transaction. So he must pay the stamp duty.

Column: 285

PRIVATE CONDOMINIUMS AND HDB FLATS
(Increase in sale prices and impact on affordability)


    3. Mrs Lim Hwee Hua asked the Minister for National Development whether the average compounded increase in (a) private condominium, (b) HDB direct purchase and (c) HDB resale prices over the last (i) 5 years and (ii) 10 years has outstripped the increase in wages over the same periods, and if so, whether the resultant impact on affordability is addressed by the planned land sales.

    The Minister of State for National Development (Dr John Chen Seow Phun) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, as at the second quarter of 1999, the increase in monthly wages of workers compared with the price increase for the various categories of housing types over the last 5 and 10 years

Column: 286

are in the table (Cols. 397-398) which I shall now ask the Clerk of Parliament to circulate to Members. My staff told me that they have given the table to Parliament.
Table - Trends of Wages vs Property Prices (Cols. 397-398)


    Mr Speaker: Please continue while we get the table.

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, as shown in the table, the price increase of new HDB flats is generally in line with wage increases over the same periods. This is because HDB takes into account wage increases when adjusting prices of new flats. In this way, the Government ensures that new HDB flats remain affordable to the majority of Singaporeans.

    In the absence of the table, maybe I will just go through the table which is very simple. Let me say that the monthly wage increase over the last five years is about 6% per annum. If it is over the last 10 years, it is about 7% per annum. Whereas for new HDB flat prices, the increase over the last 5 years is about 5% per annum, as opposed to 6% for the increase in monthly wages. And the increase over the last 10 years is 7% per annum, as opposed to 7% per annum increase for the monthly wages.

    For resale HDB flat prices, the increase over the last 5 years is 7% per annum, and the increase over the last 10 years is 12% per annum. For private condominium prices, the increase over the last 5 years is 0% per annum, and the increase over the last 10 years is 9% per annum. Sir, as I have said earlier, the Government ensures that new HDB flats remain affordable to the majority of Singaporeans.

    On the other hand, prices of resale HDB flats are determined by market forces. Resale flats cater mainly to HDB upgraders who have the benefit of capital gains from the sale of their previous HDB flats. First-timers who wish to purchase resale flats can apply for the CPF Housing Grant Scheme. The grant, which is as much as $40,000 for those applying to live near their parents, can be used to pay for the downpayment of the resale

Column: 287

flats. In this way, the Government helps to enhance the affordability of resale flats for first-timers.

    As for private condominiums, current prices are at the same level as 5 years ago. Over the last 10 years, as I said, condominium prices have increased at about 9% per annum, which is slightly higher than the corresponding wage increase of 7% per annum.

    Prices and affordability of private residential properties are determined by the market. Government cannot set prices for private property, like new HDB flats. However, Government can and will ensure that there is sufficient land set aside for private housing to meet the medium term demand. This is done under the regular Government land sales (GLS) programme. The Government will also ensure regular release of comprehensive and accurate information on the private property market to enable buyers and sellers to make informed decisions. In this way, the Government can contribute to a stable property market, where prices generally move in line with prevailing economic conditions.

    Mrs Lim Hwee Hua (Marine Parade): Sir, I have two supplementary questions for the Minister of State. Firstly, what would the Minister of State consider to be entry level housing, and whether the increase in the selling prices of such housing has actually kept pace with the increase in wages for the relevant segment of the population?

    Secondly, given the faster increase in prices of resale flats, whether the revision of the income ceiling for eligibility for direct purchase from HDB has taken this into account, and whether these have been made in tandem with the wage increase for first-timers; specifically, whether at least the same percentage of people is eligible with each revision of the income ceiling?

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, for entry level, if you look at the 4-room flats and

Column: 288

with the average income household of, say, $2,700, it would usually take about 4-5 years for the couple to be able to pay the 20% downpayment for the flat, and thereafter paying only about 17% of their household income for the monthly mortgage, and that 17% can be paid fully through their CPF contributions. Therefore, we can say that it is actually very affordable. The entry level is actually quite low.

    As for the ceiling, we have revised the ceiling over the years. Let me give the Member some indication of the ceiling revision. In 1989, it was about $5,000 for 3-, 4-, 5-room and Executive flats. For an extended family, it was $8,000, ie, 3-tier family which includes the grandparents. In 1991, we revised it to $6,000; in 1992, $7,000; 1994, $8,000. In 1995, with the introduction of the Executive Condominiums (EC), we raised it to $10,000, for applicants to qualify for EC. In 1996, we had the anti-speculation measures, and followed by the economic crisis. So, since then, there was no revision for the ceiling.

    Let me just give the Member some statistics to put the issue in perspective. If you look at applicants who apply for 4-room and 5-room flats, which is in the range of $7,000-$8,000, it is less than 1% of the applicants who apply for 4-and 5-room flats and who are in the monthly income range of $7,000-$8,000. It shows that the large majority are basically up to $5,000 monthly income, which means that the income ceiling is pretty generous. In fact, the $10,000 income ceiling covers 92% of the Singaporean household income. I would say that if you look at the long-term target of the proportion of Singaporeans who own public housing versus private housing, it is 75% versus 25%. So, I would say that at this income ceiling, it is really very generous.

KIDNAPPING
(Publicity on laws and punishment)


    4. Dr Lily Neo asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) whether the team that handled the recent case of kidnapping has been highly commended, and (b) whether

Column: 289

there are plans to publicise widely our laws and punishment concerning kidnapping, especially to foreigners in the country.

    The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, the team that handled the recent case of kidnapping did a good job in solving the case quickly and arresting the kidnappers. They also recovered the bulk of the ransom money. The victim was also released unharmed. As in all such cases, officers who excel will be appropriately recognised by the Police and my Ministry.

    Sir, the recent kidnapping case attracted extensive media coverage for about a week. During this time, the press repeatedly publicised that the serious offence of kidnapping attracts the death penalty. There will be more publicity when the case goes to Court. I am sure that the swift and resolute action of CID is additional strong deterrence to would-be kidnappers. Foreigners are also warned of the tough laws in Singapore when they come to our country to work.

Column: 289

BICYCLISTS TRAVELLING ALONG PUBLIC THOROUGHFARES
(Regulations)


    5. Mr Heng Chiang Meng asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) whether there are regulations for bicyclists when travelling along public thoroughfares to ensure the safety of themselves and other road-users; and (b) if there are, what is the number of bicyclists caught for violation of such regulations for the past year as well as the punishments meted out for such violations.

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Sir, cyclists on roads are required to obey the same traffic rules as motorists. Additionally, the Road Traffic (Bicycle) Rules set out the manner in which cyclists should conduct themselves whilst on the road. They also stipulate safety requirements such as brakes and headlamps. The purpose is to

Column: 290

ensure the safety of the cyclists as well as other road users.

    In 1998, Traffic Police issued 115 summonses to cyclists. These were for more serious offences such as riding against the flow of traffic and riding abreast of other cyclists. A typical composition fine of $20 was imposed. Cyclists who commit minor offences are usually counselled and let off with a warning.

    Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Cheng San): Sir, is the Minister of State aware that there are many bicycles being used at night on the road without headlamps or reflector lights?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: I think it is a subjective view, but there will certainly be bicyclists who flout the law. I want to assure the Member that what the Traffic Police will do is to step up public education. This is one focus where Traffic Police will put more effort, targetting, in particular, the elderly, working through, for example, SAGE and the People's Association as well as foreign workers through their employers.

    Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Sir, I do not believe it is a matter of subjective view. Would the Minister of State ask some company to do a survey because, currently, without registration, most bicycles are used on the roads without headlights or reflector lights at night. And very often, for some strange reasons, the bicyclists normally wear dark clothings, making them both a danger to themselves as well as to other road users. Just for the Minister of State's information, I had a personal experience where I nearly knocked into a bicyclist. Thereafter, I made it a point to observe such bicyclists on the roads. From my own personal survey, I would say that the majority of them do not use headlights.

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: As I have assured the Member, we have got the rules which are there. Indeed, all cyclists should be reminded that they are also part of the traffic and therefore they should abide by the traffic rules. Having said this, whilst enforcement is important, on the

Column: 291

other hand, given the wide range of cyclists where you have young children and the elderly, we should also remember that public education is another arm that should be embarked on. Indeed, police will take these two approaches of enforcement and public education.

    Mr Heng Chiang Meng: May I ask of the Minister of State whether the police will step up enforcement because I had personally observed policemen actually ignoring such infringements?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: It depends on the nature of the offence. Like I have said, in the more serious offences, for example, cycling against the flow of traffic, police indeed have issued such summonses. Indeed, over the years, the number of summonses has gone up. I will inform the police of the Member's concern and, where appropriate, enforcement would be carried out.

    Mr Heng Chiang Meng: May I ask something specifically of the Minister? If a bicycle is used on the public thoroughfare without a headlight, and if a policeman happens to be standing by, would the policeman ignore such an offence, or would he try to stop the cyclist and take down the particulars of the cyclist?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Like I have said, there is a range of options open to the police officer. In some situations, they have given warnings, which is also an option. In other cases, they have issued summonses. So I would say it depends on the facts of each case.

The concerns of the milieus cut across races - it is the same for each milieu, whatever their race. Perhaps, it is the desire to be

Column: 310

sensitive that we do not want to recognise this divide. But in so doing, we become less sensitive to each other's needs.

    There cannot be social cohesion if any one milieu feels, rightly or wrongly, that it is being treated unfairly. It is only by conscious effort that such misunderstandings can be minimised. There is a need to find ways to explain policies in the language and in the context of each milieu.

    Much attention was paid to involve a cross section of Singaporeans in the development of the S21 vision. However, at the end of the day, the intelligentsia are the ones who packaged and presented it to the people. The challenge is to help people of all milieus see that S21 is for them and that they all have a role to play. The people who keep our environment clean and healthy must see that they too are contributing to the well-being of our nation and are just as important as those generating exports. It is only when everyone at every stratum can feel that they are playing an important role in the progress of our nation that the spirit of S21 can take root, be nourished and grow.

    Social cohesion must be the foundation, the canvas upon which we sketch and paint our vision for tomorrow. Without social cohesion, we have little chance of completing the picture of Singapore in the new millennium. The sketching presented will end up as just blotches of paint with clashing colours and shades, to be passed on as 21st century art. It may belong to everyone but only a few will appreciate it.

    Assoc. Prof. Toh See Kiat (Aljunied): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the motion standing in the name of Mr Davinder Singh.

    The President in his Address promised that the Government will be promoting active citizenship "to get Singaporeans to play a full part in shaping our future." Mr Singh has waxed lyrical about active citizenship and I cannot match his eloquence and wisdom on the subject. I wish merely to add two points to help us

Column: 311

understand the full import of these two simple words.

    First, active citizens must have realistic and informed expectations and opinions. Second, active citizens must learn to disagree without being divisive. Let me elaborate.

    As Mr Singh pointed out in his speech, we have a new generation of Singaporeans who expect to be consulted and to have their voices heard. The Government has promised to hear them. At the same time, as Mr Singh has noted, those who propose alternatives must be prepared to defend them in the robust arena of debate. I would add that the debate, to be meaningful, must also be well-informed and have realistic expectations. Otherwise, the debate will end up with no greater merit than the bar brawl over a drunkard's view of the world.

    For example, those who argue for more financial welfare for the poor, along the lines of western social systems, lose their credibility if they do not know why the very societies which have these systems are trying to ditch them. As Mr Lim Boon Heng pointed out on Monday, welfare and minimum wage levels in these countries are predicated upon providing the poor with shelter and basic needs, with the bulk of the aid going to the cost of shelter. In Singapore, 90% of our people already own their own homes. Demanding the same level or model of welfare would be uninformed, unrealistic, unwise and an altogether unfair debating point.

    As another example, journalist Chua Lee Hoong has expressed her dismay that MPs in this House are not following up on each other's points, affirming, elaborating or countering. She totally misunderstands the purpose of a Parliamentary debate to thank the President for his Address. Procedurally, the debate is on Mr Singh's motion, whether or not to thank the President. It is a device for Members to explore the issues raised by the President's Address and the Addenda. If we were to debate Mr Singh's points

Column: 312

alone, this would be a very narrow debate indeed! She has probably also not informed herself of how debate is carried out in other Parliaments. Her criticism is thus unfair, as unfair as her comment that His Excellency the President's Address is devoid of wit and passion.

    One, the President's Address is a ceremonial speech outlining the Government's programme. It is not a politician's speech. The passion within it is understated. Surely, she does not expect him to punctuate his Speech with shouts of "Merdeka"? Has she never seen the Queen of England deliver similar speeches in stately fashion? The Constitutional convention allows for passion only in politicians' speeches!

    Two, Miss Chua certainly has not seen Parliamentarians debating in the Lok Sabha in India. There, as here, Parliamentary time is short, the opportunities to speak limited and the agenda long. Parliamentarians need to espouse the views of their constituents; they have to push the interests and promote programmes for the well-being of those they represent. So, in the Lok Sabha, it is a common sight to see several MPs all talking at the top of their voices at the same time. Would they be listening to each other, I wonder?

    On the other hand, you have the fine example of Congressmen in the US House of Representatives. I visited that august institution in 1985 when the House was in session. In a chamber that sits 435 people, I saw a handful seated and one standing and speaking. At first, I thought he was rehearsing his speech, until I saw the Speaker of the House move to make a ruling on something. In the US Congress, the more important work is done in its hallowed halls - and thus the word "lobby" - not in the debating chamber. Not many Congressmen were listening to his debate to counter it.

    This House, Sir, I am glad to say, is more orderly than the Lok Sabha and more diligent than the US House of Representatives. We have many points to push, many petitions to plead, and some pet projects to promote. We do not do it for show, but

Column: 313

to air the views of our citizens. To paraphrase the Senior Minister who said this before in this House, if what Members say in here do not resonate outside, we are done for. The debate on the President's Address is not a school debate with thrust and counter thrust. In the past, many ideas were floated in these debates, some of which were later picked up by the Front Bench and incorporated into the Government's programmes. We do not wish it any other way.

    My second point on active citizens is that we must learn to disagree without coming to blows. Robust debate is not necessarily a personal attack. Passion must not be mistaken for aggression. As Mr Singh asked, "Can we take the heat?" If we cannot, we should not stay in the kitchen.

    When I was a student in America, and again in England, I often saw my friends argue with each other (and even with the Professors) until their faces were blue. And yet, they never became enemies. Here, in our culture, the moment you contradict someone just a little too vigorously, you have lost a friend. For active citizens to benefit from active debates, we must learn to take as well as we give, and adjourn for a happy drink together afterwards. "Defeat" can be accepted with grace, not a feeling of humiliation. Disagreement does not mean division.

    Once we have learnt that we can agree to disagree, it would not make headlines anymore every time a Minister appears to disagree with another, or a Member of Parliament does not align himself with a Government position. It does not mean that the PAP has begun to split, nor that the Member in question is embittered and is "hitting out". Such is the grist of active gossip, not citizenship.

    When we have occasion to disagree with the Government, we must have the conviction that we are right and are ready to defend our stand. That is why we must be well-informed. If we hit hard, we must expect to be hit hard. As Mr Singh said, in moving this motion, this Government is

Column: 314

not known for the subtlety of its replies. Perhaps as time goes by, all of us will learn how to modulate our blows in debate, though the calibration is an art to be learnt from experience, not a science that is acquired from the books. While we call on the Government to be more thick-skinned when criticised, we must not apply double standards. The active citizen must learn to be thick-skinned too! Ask Mr Simon Tay, or perhaps Prof. Walter Woon. No active citizen should throw in the towel and proclaim that he has stopped because he is now cowering in fear. If he fears his own shadow, the public forum and its floodlights is not a place where he should be found.

    The President in his Address offered another set of buzzwords: Singapore as a "knowledge-based economy". Sir, permit me next to say a few words on this topic.

    Knowledge is acquired, usually from education. This is probably why many Members before me have majored on educational reform. Our educational system has traditionally been knowledge-intensive, pressed down by dedicated drill masters. In the Information Age, however, knowledge has a very short shelf life. What you learn in school may become obsolete a short six years after you graduate. It is not productive in such a world to cram our children with knowledge. We must equip them with skill sets which will help them acquire useful knowledge all through their lives and sound values for them to discern between good and evil.

    Education in such a world should not be examination-interrupted as it is currently. There are important examinations at the end of Primary 3, 4, 6; Secondary 2, 4 and Junior College. If we set aside two months to prepare for each examination, we would have wasted a full one year doing nothing but cram. We would have lost productivity in the economy too, because parents have to take leave from work to rehearse the children for their examinations. Perhaps school in the future will not be examination-interrupted but examination-terminated. One graduation examination, the 'A' levels. I am thrilled therefore that

Column: 315

the Minister for Education is taking a step in that direction by considering dropping the 'O' level for some students.

    We want "thinking schools". For that not to be an empty slogan, we must allow students time to think; time to be creative; time to sieve good from bad, gold from dross. On the Internet, there are lots of information, and misinformation. Our children must learn how to choose and discern what is harmful and what is not. If school is full of examinations and cramming, how would they find time to think? Ian Buruma condemns us as a nation afraid to think. Actually, our problem is that we have no time to think. To my knowledge, only a certain Member without a constituency is afraid to think, as I noticed that he plagiarised a whole chunk of Buruma's article and passed it off as his own analysis of Singapore in his speech during this debate.

    Our children are so busy that they have no time to be children, no time to play. I agree wholeheartedly with Mr Peh Chin Hua that we should stop driving them from class to class, tuition to tuition, enrichment programme to enrichment programme. To everything, there is a season - a season for study, a season for play; a season for stress, a season for de-stress. Play is productive, even creative. Why are we so afraid to let our children play? So afraid that we teach them Primary One things in kindergarten!

    I am so glad that the Senior Minister of State for Education has declared that henceforth this will stop. I do hope that the Ministry will next stop the hideous practice of ranking schools purely on academic performance. Rank if you must, but do not forget to give high scores to schools which give their students a balanced education, rounding them up with sports, arts and character-building programmes.

    The President's Address has clearly stated that school curricula will be revised to cater for these. I am deeply appreciative, as many Singaporean parents would be, with that promise.

Column: 316



    With the one year that we save in not having examinations, we should send our children for sports and music camps perhaps, or SIF overseas volunteer programmes, student exchange programmes, Operation Raleigh projects, Outward Bound School. We should challenge them to climb Mt Everest, Mt Kinabalu or at least Mt Ophir. Presently, they do not even have time to climb Mt Faber! We cannot allow this to continue.

    At the end of the day, we must not forget that we have taught them to pledge, "to build a democratic society, based on justice and equality, so as to achieve happiness, prosperity and progress for our nation." They cannot learn about a democratic society by suffering six major examinations in 12 years of schooling. They must leave their books and visit Parliament, the courts, the civil institutions. They cannot learn about justice and equality from textbooks and endless assessment papers. They must experience these from interaction with their classmates, multi-racial classmates at that, and with their community.

    In conclusion, Sir, let me say that hitherto, the Government in all its policies has over-emphasised, dare I say, "achieving prosperity and progress" and left out "happiness" for the most part. The Chinese version of our pledge refers to "happiness" as xin fu (    ) which, loosely translated, can mean "blessing". Blessing is a state of contentment, much deeper than happiness, and it comes from spiritual and emotional well-being. Even happiness itself cannot come simply from material prosperity and progress. Happiness comes from fond memories of Singapore, our home. Our hearts must beat, as the President said in his Address, for Singapore - for its foods and smells, for its sounds and colours, its history, its landmarks and its people.

    We must learn to restrain our urge to demolish every building we see that does not fit into our plans. We must stop removing the landmarks of our history. Architectural merit must not be the only consideration for preservation. I regret, for example, the demolition of my alma mater

Column: 317

many years ago in the past, the first school in Singapore with a very, very large history, because it was not economical or distinctive enough architecturally to save. Is the National Library building at Stamford Road really not possible to save and refurbish for future generations to mark our history?

    Happiness too, Sir, comes from making life more meaningful for others, especially those less fortunate than ourselves. That is active citizenship. Happiness too comes from having fun. We say that every Singaporean counts. His welfare counts. For him, we need to make Singapore a fun place to live in, not just because it helps us to make a quick tourist dollar, but because it is what we have pledged to do. I am glad that finally in MITA's programmes, we have a plan to promote fun in Singapore. As many of our Western friends might say, "Come on Singapore, loosen up!"

    Sir, I support the motion.

    Mr Simon Tay: Sir, I am grateful to join in this debate. I wish to speak on this Government's promise to focus on people and to promote active citizenship. In so doing, there are three fundamental questions we need to ask ourselves: (1) Why is this important? (2) What specifically should and will be done, and by whom? (3) What obstacles and limits stand in our way?

    Allow me to begin with an observation not about Singapore but about Vietnam, where I have been and why I missed the first two days of this debate. We are not alone in facing change and the new millennium for our society. Vietnam is in something of a dilemma. They recognise that they need to open up their country to the world market and to foreign investors. This is their doi moi policy. However, they are concerned about foreign influence on their society and how society and politics will change as they open up. So they seem to muddle through.

    A very astute observer remarked to me, "the problem is that they won the war." The problem is that they won the war. This statement is not to wish that they lost. But

Column: 318

this statement acutely sees the problem of success. When you have won the war, you believe you have the formula for success. You have the veterans you must take care of, and a system that brought victory. It is therefore very hard to change, to say, "we need something new". Instead, there is some tinkering, some muddling around, half measures. In this sense, past success inhibits real and necessary change to meet the future.

    In contrast, where people lose, there is justification and occasion for widespread change. Something like what Japan experienced after World War II, just as before, in the Meiji restoration. A crisis and a failure bring a country the opportunity for a deep change, a transformation. Japan is, by the way, now looking at a commission, much like the Singapore 21, on Japan's role in the 21st century.

    Singapore, of course, is very different from Vietnam or Japan. We did not fight the kind of war (although in the 1970s, the conventional wisdom said that we might if the dominoes in Southeast Asia fell). But we did win through another struggle for economic success and survival. We too had succeeded.

    In achieving this success, this victory, we have our own veterans and our own system of society and politics. These have served us well in the past and in the present, and it is very difficult to abandon them abruptly. Indeed, there are those among us who also fear that if we open up too fast, they are not sure what influences will work on our society, and change our politics.

    Are we then too successful to truly change? Will we just simply tinker around and hope to muddle through the 21st century? Or can we truly commit ourselves to necessary and real change for an active people sector? Much depends on our motivation.

Why do we need active citizens?

    This brings me to my first point. Why do we need this change? Why do we need active citizens? Why do we need people to

Column: 319

actively participate in the nation's affairs? The Presidential Address gives us two main reasons for this goal. First, active citizens can improve Government policies. Second, active citizenship and participation gives people a stake in the country. The second of these two reasons - giving all a stake - ties with the overall goal of developing stronger social cohesion to make sure we gel together as a people. This is important as we prepare for a knowledge-based economy because such an economy will tend to reward people very differently and can potentially divide us.

    The call for active citizenship in this sense has a very rational economic basis. First, and most immediately, we can improve on policies. Second, and more broadly, "heartware" is to be the social bond for a vast and rapid economic change.

    Are these rational and economic reasons enough to motivate real and necessary change? Some Singaporeans will, of course, always queue up if there is a sale. If there is a dollar sign, they will queue up. For some people, it is. But not for all of us, and not always. Some of us respond to other stimulus.

    One of these is the goal of becoming a "democracy". When I use this word, I do not want to embroil this House in a debate about definitions. Democracy is a loaded term. It is often used to mean a certain form of liberal democracy, as we see in some Western societies. But here, I use the word "democracy", in the terms of our own pledge. We pledge to build a "democratic society, based on justice and equality". If we hold true to this goal, this ideal of democracy, this can be a third and potent reason to have active citizens. In a democracy, more than any other society or system, people count. Literally they vote, and their vote counts. More than that, they participate in the society and in the political processes.

    In this sense, I do not see that active citizens are an option, a luxury for good

Column: 320

times. They are essential to face the coming challenges for Singapore to be a home amidst the open, competitive, rapidly changing and often turbulent world that is coming. We should not wish for a crisis or to lose a war in order to have real change. But we have to be motivated for real change. Only then can the goals set by the Presidential Address be reached.

    In this regard, I must confess that I am disappointed on this point of active citizens by the plans announced by the different Ministries in their Addenda to the Presidential Address.

What specifically should and will be done, and by whom?

    Let me deal with this in the second question: What specifically should and will be done, and by whom? If we go through the Addenda of the different Ministries, there are relatively few references to plans to make active citizenship possible. Perhaps they have their own more immediate concerns with existing policies and plans. There is, after all, no Ministry in overall charge of this initiative for active citizens.

    Where the Ministries do mention plans for active citizens, these plans do not seem to me to go very far beyond what we already have. Take, for example, the Ministry of Community Development's plans for the Feedback Unit. This Unit is very important for active citizens to be heard and to also listen. But if you look at paragraph 9 of the Addendum, and I quote:

    "The Feedback Unit will reach out to more Singaporeans to obtain varied and representative feedback. It will also inform and explain to opinion makers and grassroots leaders the rationale and details of Government policies."



    How is this different from what they have done before and what they are doing now? Why is the emphasis still on a downward communication to opinion makers and grassroots leaders to explain to them why policies are as they are? If there is no difference, and an emphasis on downward communication, how will this

Column: 321

status quo promote the change towards an active citizen sector?

    The plans by the Ministry of Information and the Arts are similar in this regard. It talks about the access to information and again this is obviously very important to an active people sector. But there seems in their Addenda to be more concern that the greater and easier access to information will impinge on economic, social and political life. While this is true and should be studied, I would have hoped that there would be an equal study on enabling citizens to have use of greater access to become more knowledgeable and aware of important issues facing our society. This will be the necessary basis, the foundation, for more informed, reasoned and active people.

    I turn next to the Prime Minister's Office. I was heartened here to see a subsection of the Addendum entitled "Towards Active Citizenship", and by the pledge in this Addendum to have the public service play its part towards attaining this goal. But the particulars of the Addendum fall short, in my view.

    The promise here is to "consult the private and public sectors more, in order to obtain feedback, tap their specialised knowledge, and [I want to emphasise] ensure smoother implementation of Government's policies."

    "Smoother implementation of Government's policies" is a necessary and helpful step. But it is not enough for an active people. Active citizens are not just there to help Government policy implementation.

    In this regard, it is worth pointing out that all of us citizens have at least three parts - hands, a heart and a head. Government wants helping hands. Government increasingly wants the hearts of Singaporeans too, if this is to be our home. But it is less clear from the various plans whether Government also wants the head. Not on a chopping block. But a head, a mind that can independently think and want to propose or oppose policies, rather than just helping smoother implementation. And with that head comes mouths that can freely and reasonably speak.

Column: 322



    What the Ministries have proposed is a start, but a very modest one at best. The Singapore 21 Committee on the idea of active citizens went quite a bit further. The subject committee which I chaired with Mr Lim Swee Say, now Minister of State, on "consensus and consultation against decisiveness and quick action" made a number of concrete suggestions that have yet to find a place in the Addenda announced by Government. I hope perhaps they will.

    In making these points, I want to emphasise that I am not arguing for free licence and a rowdy free-for-all. Those who argue against a status quo can often be mischaracterised in this way, and they find their proposals labelled "radical" or "unrealistic".

    The approach I am arguing for finds its analogy in the liberalisation of the financial sector. First, we must have a broad vision of what the Government wants and an identification of present limits. Second, we need a recognition that while Government will have a regulatory role, that role has changed. Third, we need an emerging practice that shows all the practitioners concerned that the philosophy and tools for regulation have changed. And, fourth, we need a series of measures that will push and change the existing limits. In financial liberalisation, the Government's approach has been, I believe, for a series of "small bangs". Not radical, but readily discernible. Measured but measurable.

    I would call for a similar approach to the liberalisation of our laws and policies towards an active people sector. And I am disappointed that I do not find such a series of small bangs in the Ministerial Addenda.

    But while I criticise, I certainly do not want to be seen as an armchair critic, or even a Parliamentary chair critic. I and my fellow NMP, Zulkifli Baharudin, will undertake a study on civil society in 21st century Singapore. We will roll up our sleeves as an active citizen, do our part to study this problem. The study will focus

Column: 323

on three areas: (1) the registration of societies; (2) the limits to speech and assembly, especially in public; and (3) the role of private foundations and Government agencies in supporting and fostering civil society organisations.

    These are, to us, three of the key limits and obstacles to a more active people sector. Mr Zulkifli and I do not prejudge what the conclusions of the study will be. In each area, while there is a need for more openness, there may also be valid reasons for limits and obstacles.

    Take the first area, for example. The registration of societies is fundamental to having active citizens organise themselves. If they do not register, they may be considered illegal and prosecuted. Yet, it is within the discretion of the Registrar of Societies to refuse their registration on a number of grounds. So some cases take time. In comparison, the registration of private companies is automatic and easy. There are historical reasons for this, and also some present day concerns. We therefore have to more closely examine how to balance the needs, on the one hand, of a more active people sector to organise themselves and be lawfully registered and recognised, with, on the other hand, the need for caution and control.

    In the second area too of public speech, I think there is a need to examine the balance. It cannot be, on the one hand, that we allow speech without responsibility, and allow for sedition, racial slurs, defamation, mis-information and possible disorder in the streets. But, on the other hand, should we continue to have all public speech, including that on political and social issues, licensed under a Public Entertainment Act, and decided by some faceless bureaucrats? In comparison, our censorship of films has, in the last decade, moved far beyond this already.

    Let me at this juncture, mention this debate about having thick skin. In my case, I think, it is more just bad skin which people mistake for thick skin. I want to

Column: 324

point out that, of course, people who want to participate in public debate must have thick skin. But I also want to emphasise the question of whether, in this robust engagement, it is truly equal and truly fair. The analogy I have, in a sense, is traffic. We all drive. You may have a car, I may have a car. Others drive in bigger cars and some of us may be bus drivers. Buses today are big, fast, turbo-charged. Both cars and buses have honks. I may sound my "horn", or to use Singlish, I may horn. But if I am driving a car and I honk, it does not mean that I will be able to engage the bus, even if it is in the wrong. He is probably a wiser man who values his car, his life and that of his passengers who gives way to the bus. I think this analogy needs careful consideration when we talk about debates between a fledgling, young people sector with an established strong, knowledgeable and determined Government.

    These are some of the issues that we hope to consider in our study over the next few months and to seek a new balance for. But, as I said, I do not prejudge our conclusions. What I can tell you is our approach. We will consult and canvass our initial thoughts with relevant actors, especially those in civil society and also those in relevant Government agencies. We will aim for consensus. But that is not always possible. I think we should not water down our study to the lowest common denominator. Therefore, we will not shy away from controversy.

    We hope to coach and also to criticise. We hope to persuade and debate and also press. Those who do not have power, who do not sit in the seat of power in Government, can do no more. But active citizens should do no less. With this, I support the motion.

    Dr Michael Lim Chun Leng (Cheng San): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in the debate on the motion to thank the President.

    The next millennium will be a different era from this century. Two major trends will have a major impact on Singapore in the next century. The socio-economic

Column: 325

landscape of Singapore will be transformed by the Internet and information technology revolution and the small modern Singapore family will face the challenges of managing an increasingly aging population.

    The emphasis on people development, active citizenship and development of heartware will take a different dimension with the explosion of the Internet, broadband technology, wireless technology and other developments in the IT revolution.

    The IT revolution will change the social and economic landscape of the world. As we prepare the younger generation in our educational institutions for the future, we must also prepare ourselves for the consequences of the IT explosion, especially the Internet. The Internet will have far-reaching implications for Singapore.

    In the Internet world, speed is everything, and the extremely fast pace of development has opened an entirely new social and economic virtual world that only the Internet-savvy can keep pace with. Entirely new businesses have sprouted out that have grown rapidly to challenge established institutions. Many virtual Internet companies are now worth more than their competitors and are increasingly eating into the economic pie of the real world competitors. Those who have the vision to understand the power of the Internet and harness its power will be leaders in the next economic revolution.

    In the mid-70s when this American Charles Schwab decided to transform his full-service brokerage into a discount brokerage firm, he insisted, against a trend, that he would develop in-house technology. He placed his bet on technology and signed a cheque that was equal to the entire net worth of his company. By 1996 it had begun offering Web training. In January 1998, it weaved all its electronic services into one integrated service. Now, according to the IT research firm company, IDC, Charles Schwab & Company commands more than 70% of the assets traded online, and

Column: 326

its trading volume is that of its nearest three competitors combined. Worth US$36.5 billion, Charles Schwab & Company is widely acknowledged as the only traditional retail operation, financial services or otherwise, to have successfully adapted its business to the Web. Charles Schwab has become bigger than established financial institutions, like Merryl Lynch.

    The success story is not only confined to USA. Despite a non-supportive environment in Japan, Mr Mikitani, a 1988 graduate in Japan, launched his Internet site in 1997, and since then he has developed Rakuten into the most popular online business-to-consumer e-commerce designation in Japan, averaging approximately US$3.5 million in transactions every month and more than 400,000 visits per day. He said, "In Japan, everyone was pessimistic about e-commerce, and I wanted to do something that everyone was pessimistic about." Two-and-a-half years later, Rakuten has become Japan's largest on-line shopping mall, providing auction, hosting and transaction-processing services and market-analysis tools to more than 750 of Japan's largest companies.

    The Internet will affect every industry. Interactive video on demand, music on the Internet and the broadband revolution are shaking up the entertainment industry. No business will be spared.

    For Singapore to be relevant in the next century, we must become a top class Internet and technological hub. We must have the right ingredients to succeed.

    The essential ingredient we have to add to ignite any significant revolutionary development in the information technology industry is the entrepreneur or technopreneur. A rare species, they are imbued with clear vision, great foresight, utmost determination, inexhaustible drive, extreme passion, immense resourcefulness and perhaps a foolhardy love for risk. The spirit of the entrepreneurs exudes boundless and infective optimism that drives the belief that they can achieve the most wonderful things in

Column: 327

the face of gargantuan obstacles. For any market or economy to prosper, entrepreneuers are indispensable. They are the agents of change. As the economist Lester Thurow observes in his latest book, Building Wealth, "Change requires individuals who recognize that new things can be done and who take the initiative to get them done. . The existing bureaucracies, public and private, will not take on the job of changing what is."

    Our bureaucracies will have to constantly modify the rules to create a conducive environment that will ensure that the entrepreneur will thrive. We have taken some concrete measures but more needs to be done. I have been told by companies that have taken grants from NSTB that they lament about the bureaucracy. Perhaps it is time to review the administration of such grants to IT companies to establish a comfortable balance between protecting the interest of NSTB and the non-hindrance of company efficiency.

    Mindsets have to be changed. The Internet will make the world a giant information hub. Information cannot be hidden as Internet allows us to harness the wealth of information on the Net. For example, health and medical information sites in the USA provide equal access to all users, regardless of whether he is a medical doctor or a lay person. However, many Singapore sites tend to bar the lay public from the restricted areas which are only accessible to professionals. The irony of it is that the same information, or even better information, is available on the US sites and accessible to the lay public. Singaporeans must learn to understand that the Internet world is a borderless world. Instead of hiding information, we can play an important role in optimising the use of information available.
