This is our bold strategy to tackle the challenges ahead.

    A first-world economy and a world-class home are not two separate goals. They are two sides of the same coin. We need the resources from a sound, competitive economy to build a world-class home, and we need a world-class home to anchor Singaporeans to create a first-world economy for Singapore.

    Between the two facets, a first-world economy is the easier goal to achieve. Our economic foundation is strong and our reputation as a pro-business economy is

Column: 347

excellent. By implementing the right policies consistently and building new capabilities, we will succeed in becoming a first-world economy.

    Building a world-class home presents a trickier challenge. It is not just about nice houses, modern conveniences and bright city lights. It is about people, relationships, motivation, commitment, passion, dedication and determination. The irony is that the more Singapore improves its infrastructure and amenities, the less unique and indistinguishable from other cities it becomes. Singapore risks becoming like one of those well-run, comfortable international hotels which successful business executives check in and out.

Building a world-class home

    What makes a home different from a hotel is where the heart is. Most homes are less comfortable than a hotel, but they are where the people feel they belong, where they are king and where they can decorate and arrange the furniture anyway they like. This, in essence, is what distinguishes a home from a hotel. Singapore is a place where Singaporeans can be themselves, where they can make a difference, and where they care for one another and rally together when faced with challenges. The best home for Singaporeans is a world-class home.

    Here, I want to highlight two demographic trends which may undermine our effort to build our world-class home.

Falling fertility rates

    The first trend concerns the growth of the population. The statistics show clearly that we are not replacing ourselves. This is a serious problem. The Government has warned against this trend 12 years ago. We tried to reverse it but we have not been successful.

    Our Total Fertility Rate or TFR has fallen steadily since 1990, despite our scrapping the "Stop At Two" policy and encouraging

Column: 348

married couples to "Have three or more, if you can afford it". The TFR is a fertility indicator which shows whether the population is replacing itself. A population is considered to be replacing itself if it can maintain a TFR of about two. This means a woman in our population would on average have two children in her lifetime. Our TFR has fallen steadily from 1.87 in 1990 to 1.5 in 1998.

    1998 was the Year of the Tiger so one would not expect a large number of births. But the Year of the Rabbit has not been prolific either. The number of births in the first eight months is, in fact, 3% lower than that of the same period last year. Unless the Rabbit surprises us in the next three months, the TFR for 1999 is likely to fall below 1.5.

    In 1987 when I announced the Government's New Population Policy, I also expressed the hope that there would be at least 50,000 births a year. This provides the minimum cohort size to sustain our economy, defence and other manpower needs. Our actual birth numbers were nowhere near the 50,000 mark in the past five years. In 1998, the number of births came to only 43,664, far short of the target that the Government set.

    If this declining fertility trend persists, and it is likely to be the case, our citizen population of three million will grow to about 3.5 million by 2030 and then start to decline. Ang Mong Seng and Dr Michael Lim raised the needs of the old. The needs of the old will become even more acute after 2030. The proportion of older people then will be far higher compared to what it is today. There will also be fewer people in the working-age group. This means that the 3.5 million people in Singapore in 2030 may not produce sufficient wealth to look after the needs of the old and society in general. Can a shrinking population sustain a first-world economy?

    The statistics also show that the more educated mothers are, the fewer kids they are likely to have. The more educated have on average a family size that is about 15% smaller than those with lower education. As the educational standard of

Column: 349

our people will go up, we must expect our TFR to fall even further. There are many reasons for the declining TFR - urbanisation, education, changing lifestyles, singlehood and late marriages. Having babies also involve personal choices and trade-offs. I am not optimistic that we can achieve a significant increase in fertility level. But we must never give up trying to get Singaporeans who can afford it to have more children. Dr Jennifer Lee talked about incentives for fathers. I am not sure paternity leave is the solution because our main problem is the large number of highly-educated women who remain single. Among those with post-secondary qualifications, about one in five women is likely to remain single in her life time. So we must try to increase the marriage rate of our women, especially those with higher education.

Adopting an "inclusive" mindset

    Given that our citizen population is not replacing itself, we have no choice but to top up our population with new immigrants. They provide a much-needed boost to our manpower strength, augmenting shortfalls in the productive age groups and increasing our talent pool. Since we have to take in new immigrants, we should be selective, admitting only those with skills, high education and talents, from wherever they are. This way, we make sure that foreigners who become Permanent Residents and Singaporeans are a definite plus to our country. These foreign-born Singaporeans will help enhance the vibrancy and dynamism of our economy and society.

    We should make every effort to absorb these foreign-born Singaporeans into our society. We should strengthen their commitment by giving them a sense of ownership of Singapore too. This inclusive approach will ensure that a generation from now, these new Singaporeans and their children will be as nationalistic as any one of us. Their children will have to do national service as Singaporeans.

Column: 350



Singaporeans Overseas

    This brings me to the second trend - the increased number of Singaporeans going overseas. I asked the Ministry of Manpower how many Singaporeans are overseas on a long-term basis. The Ministry came up with an estimate of 150,000, which included working adults and their dependants, emigrants and students.

    Based on the number of Good Conduct Certificates issued by the Police, each year some 2,000 Singaporeans pack up their bags and emigrate. More than half are females, many of whom married foreigners and leave Singapore to join their husbands. There are also some 6,000 applications to MINDEF each year for reservist training deferment on grounds of overseas employment of duration longer than six months.

    Whether we like it or not, more Singaporeans will take wing, given the pace of globalisation and their own personal mobility. As Singaporeans become even more cosmopolitan, the issue of concern to us is whether they will become less rooted to Singapore. We now have to even compete for the hearts of Singaporeans against attractions elsewhere.

Developing each and every Singaporean

    With this background, you will appreciate better the significance of the statement - every Singaporean matters. There are not many of us to build and protect our home. So we have to provide every Singaporean with the opportunity to develop his or her potential to the fullest. We have cut down our school dropout rate. So it shocked me to learn that each year some 1,500 children, or 3% of a cohort, are not even registered for Primary One in national schools. The Ministry of Education has argued against compulsory education because the number of non-registration is considered small. But every Singaporean matters. And every Singaporean child should be given the same head start in life, ie, to attend school. I favour compulsory education,

Column: 351

at least up to Primary 4 level. Beyond that, if a child does not want to study, or wants to drop out, there is little we can do. I am asking the Ministry of Education to consider the introduction of compulsory education.

Giving Singaporeans an emotional stake

    We have given Singaporeans a physical stake in the country - home-ownership, upgrading of HDB estates, shares of privatised Government companies, cash top-up of their CPF and Medisave accounts, good infrastructure and ample facilities for sports and leisure activities.

    We must now give Singaporeans an emotional stake in the country. This is why I have made consultation and participation one of the Government's major goals. It is to give Singaporeans a bigger say in their own future, and thus bond them to Singapore. We want Singaporeans to sprout ideas to make Singapore better, take responsibility for their ideas and make them work.

    The Government has successfully tapped private sector expertise for major Government-led committees such as the Committee on Singapore's Competitiveness of 1997 and the Financial Sector Review Committee of 1998. We found the private sector involvement very useful, both in terms of coming to grips with the problem and of forging a consensus on the way forward. We will continue to involve the private sector in major review of important policies, not just in economics, but also in non-economic areas.

    At the same time, we have systematically opened up more channels for citizens to participate, to involve them in building a world-class home. Besides writing to the press, Singaporeans can channel their views through the Feedback Unit, Service Improvement Unit, Institute of Policy Studies, Members of Parliament, dialogue sessions, GPC resource panels and so on.

Column: 352



    The recently-completed Singapore 21 exercise was noteworthy for its involvement of Singaporeans from all walks of life, in particular, younger Singaporeans. Their vision and recommendations are now accepted as national policies. Due to such extensive and active participation, we were able to come up with a Singapore 21 vision which fully reflected the needs and aspirations of our people. The opposition may dismiss Singapore 21 as empty elections talk. The point is, it is a collective product of Singaporeans, and the opposition has nothing fresh to offer.

    Simon Tay expressed his disappointment that the President's Address and Addenda fell short on details on fostering an active citizenry. If the Government were to spell out each and every step, or a series of bangs, as he put it, then it is contrary to what active citizenship is all about and what we are trying to do, that is, more initiatives from the people sector. Ravindran has answered this question very well - that you want spontaneity from the people sector. What Simon Tay and Zulkifli are doing is right, that is, do a study on how to foster civil society and submit it to the Government, and then we take it from there. This is what I mean by active citizenry. You take the initiative, and not expect the Government to outline the steps all the way for you.

Turning Singapore into a nation of ideas

    Each year, thousands of Singaporeans submit their suggestions and views to the Feedback Unit. In 1997, we took the feedback process further by organising regular feedback contributors into groups. So far, 27 feedback groups have been formed. These feedback units are the people sector's equivalent of Quality Circles and Work Improvement Teams. We now want to go beyond feedback on how policies affect the people to encouraging Singaporeans to submit constructive suggestions and new ideas.

    In the Civil Service, we reward Work Improvement Teams when they submit cost-saving ideas. Singaporeans may wish to form themselves into similar work

Column: 353

improvement teams to submit ideas on any aspect of government. We will introduce an award scheme to give symbolic recognition for useful ideas put up by Singaporeans, either individually or as a team. Big ideas or small ideas, let them flow. Turn Singapore into a nation of ideas.

Consultation and Participation

    Here, let me explain what I expect of consultation and participation, to avoid misunderstanding and cynicism.

    First, consultation does not mean that every Singaporean must be consulted, or that every policy discussed with the public before it is implemented. That is not practical. If it were practical, you would not need Members of Parliament or representative government. Parliamentary democracy means electing a group of Members of Parliament to represent the people's interests. The Government consults the people mainly through their MPs, and is answerable to Parliament for its performance. That is why having good MPs who can understand the concerns and solve problems for the people is important.

    Second, when the Government consults, it is with people who have good knowledge of the subject. It consults people who can help improve the formulation of policies. It is not necessarily with people who may be affected by the policy. Every policy of the Government affects the whole population. No government consults its citizens on every policy.

    Third, Singaporeans must not expect every suggestion and idea of theirs to be accepted. If a proposal is well argued, it will get a fair hearing. Even if it is rejected, it is also valuable if it has challenged existing assumptions and thinking and provided the opportunity for the Government to reaffirm its policies.

    Fourth, while Singaporeans will have more space for political debate, it does not mean that the Government is vacating the arena. Anyone who wants a policy changed, or to set the national agenda,

Column: 354

must expect a debate with the Government. Every Government policy has been carefully considered before implementation. But anyone is free to challenge it. However, he must expect a response from the Government. The Government will defend its policies, principles and programmes openly and robustly. Not to do so is contrary to the whole purpose of public debate. If the Government remains silent, views contrary to what the Government believes is right, will soon prevail. This will confuse the ground because the public may think the Government, by its silence, agrees with the contrary views.

    Zulkifli Baharudin said that "being thick-skinned must certainly be one of the necessary pre-requisites for anyone intending to engage in public debate". No, we do not want Singaporeans to develop hides. Even the thickest hide can be stripped. We do not want a querulous population with thick skins. An important pre-requisite for public debate is a keen mind - how sound an idea is, and how it will benefit public interests.

    Let me add that those without mischievous intention or a hidden agenda need not fear a rebuttal from Government. They should not be discouraged to speak up simply because Government may challenge their views. Constructive debate is a necessary part of the process for determining what is best for Singapore. This is what consultation and participation is about.

    But those out to undermine the Government, or to wrest power from the ruling party, is another matter altogether. They must expect a political response from the Government. This political response can be extremely robust because whoever wins in the political arena will decide the future of Singapore. The PAP will guard its turf jealously, not for itself, but for the good of Singapore.

    Singapore will always be like a boat shooting the rapids. Those who have done white-water rafting would understand my analogy. They will understand the importance of the steersman as the boat

Column: 355

negotiates the rocks in a fast-flowing, frothy river. The Government is like this steersman or captain.

    I have experienced the thrills and dangers of white-water rafting in New Zealand. Once in the boat, I put my faith in the captain and do what he told me to do. Consultation took place before I stepped into the boat. Once I was in, I had to play my part as a member of the crew.

    Do not think that Singapore is sailing in calm waters and therefore we can take risks. Or that we are freer to rock the boat because we now have a sturdier boat and each one of us is equipped with a safety helmet and a life jacket.

    The political landscape of our neighbours is changing. It will affect the strategic and security environment of our region. And however well-governed Singapore is, however strong our economy is, and however united our people are, we will be reminded from time to time that we are a little red dot, or an adik, or a predominantly Chinese country within a Muslim region.

    This does not mean we have to have a siege mentality. It means we must be robust, forward-thinking and innovative to break out of the confines of our geography, which is why we are changing the way we teach in schools, and getting our people to be more resourceful, creative and better informed.

    Our revamp of the education system will lead in the future to a questioning electorate. A questioning electorate and population will demand a higher performance from Parliament and the Government. It will demand more political space, more debate.

    Will such a population throw up an alternative party to challenge the PAP, or will it throw up more good men and women to join or support the PAP and help it carry on with its work?

    Does it matter so long as it produces a group of leaders who are honest,

Column: 356

committed to Singapore and more competent than the PAP leaders? Does it matter if it is a population which understands Singapore's uniqueness and vulnerabilities and backs its leaders?

    But I do know that to survive in an intensely competitive borderless and volatile world, it does matter if we do not have a well-informed, thinking, resourceful, innovative and cohesive population with the resolve to keep Singapore going.

    This is why for the remaining term of this Parliament, we are emphasising people - numbers, quality, commitment, relationships, roots, responsibility, freedom, participation and passion. But more than talking and consultation, there must be action. This is where I salute the thousands of social workers, volunteers, grassroots leaders and others who do more than talk. They go about quietly, looking after the interests of their community and fellow Singaporeans. They are a critical part of our people sector. The Government values such people.

Conclusion

    Singaporeans, especially the younger generation, must believe firmly in what Singapore stands for - our ideals, ethos, principles and values, and be willing to do their part to safeguard our way of life. They have done well in life because the Singapore system offers them a level playing field, abundant opportunities, and a helping hand to develop their potential to the fullest. Singapore's future is in their hands. They have to make a difference to Singapore and make us proud to be Singaporeans. This is what active citizenry is about.

    If our hearts beat together for Singapore, we will succeed as a nation no matter what challenges lie ahead. [Applause.]

    Mdm Claire Chiang See Ngoh (Nominated Member): Sir, I rise in full-hearted support of this motion and thank the President for his timely pronouncement

Column: 357

that people will be the focus of the Government's policy in the new millennium.

    Sir, there has been so much debate, just a few minutes ago with PM's discourse and in the last two years on Singapore 21, in particular on how the State must create more opportunities for every citizen to contribute ideas and actions to be active citizens.

    The Government has implicitly accepted, I presume, that the relationship between the State and society need not be a "flight or fight" choice for Singaporeans. In other words, Singaporeans who are critical of certain policies need not either totally disengage - take "flight" so to speak, physically through migration or psychologically through "tuning out" - from public discourse, or "fight" by taking part in partisan politics. If they do not want to take "flight" or "fight", is there a third way? I would like to think so because I clearly do not believe that the options before us are dichotomous: that active citizenship is about whether you join the Government or against it.

    The Government, in the last two years, has been far more respectful of different viewpoints and took them seriously. A process of engagement between the State and the people sector, however unclear it is still in terms of rights and responsibilities, has begun. Nevertheless, we are still struggling and will continue to do so with regard to the amount of space the Government is prepared to give its citizens.

    Sir, I would like to cite for discussion the case of Chinese High students who organised a spontaneous signing petition to request their Principal to consider his retirement, which, to me, was a seemingly peaceful and heartfelt gesture that was absent of any ill intention. The Ministry made a public statement that students must stay off staff matters.

    I share the Ministry's concern that well-meaning and idealistic students may be made use of for purposes which students only vaguely understood. But, Sir, for

Column: 358

future references, who, how and by what standards shall we judge when to put a curb on student's civic involvement? Should we, as adults, let them take their own responsibilities as thinking individuals, by adopting a greater latitude of tolerance, even for acts which they did not always understand completely? Sir, children learn by making mistakes in doing things. While this may be frowned upon in our society, in our strive to create a zero defect and zero mistake society, we have to accept that it is a natural human limitation to make mistakes. That being so, is it not then the responsibility of the adults and the authorities to create that climate of tolerance for learning purposes?

    Like one student alumni from Chinese High said to me, "if we do not first learn to bond with the school and our Principal, how can we learn to bond with the nation?" The Chinese High students appreciated what the Principal had done for the school and wanted him to stay, an emotion that seemed natural enough. They would have liked to hear from the Ministry that this was a good thing to do too. The Ministry made them feel as though they could not act on their own without being easily manipulated. Although the Ministry did say it was understandable for students to express their feelings in a press release issued by Mrs Lim Soon Tze afterwards, the students nevertheless felt let down.

    Sir, we are talking about future leaders of Singapore. We expect them to think and make mistakes. Even if they had been influenced by the Board members whose involvement in the management of the school was inappropriate, we have to respect the students for reaching a decision to do what they did. Then it is our job to persuade them otherwise.

    Sir, I bring this up as a concerned mother because apart from academic achievement, I would like my children to get leadership experiences from their schools on civic responsibilities. But I would also be disturbed if I feel that they were being used. In this particular case, I ask what rights were the students asking

Column: 359

for? Nothing for themselves, it was simply an expression of affection and hope that the Ministry will help them to retain their Principal. What was the responsibility which they must reciprocate to get this right of expression, if we agree with Mr Davinder Singh that there cannot be greater rights without greater responsibilities? I assume in this case is to conduct the act in a peaceful manner, without disruption to school routine and order. That they had done too. So what did the students do wrong?

    If students do not care about anything, they are accused of being apathetic. If they express strong feelings about a subject which, one has to admit, they certainly have first hand feelings about, and act, as PM encourages people should do so, they are accused of being gullible and naive and manipulated by others. Is this not the classic catch-22 situation?

    Is it not wiser then to consider a leadership style of stepping back a little and "letting it be" (remember the song "Let it be" in the words of a famous baby-boomer rock singer) - a strategy of diffusing conflict and gaining some headway in a difficult situation? In Chinese, we say "yi tui wei jin" (    ). Is it not better that a separate session be spent with the entire Chinese High School to commend the students for what they have done, then explain clearly but gently that this is an administrative matter which is best settled officially? I think the students will totally agree with you because most of them did not see their act as intervening in staff matters, even less a "wish to join the picket line of employment disputes" as feared by Mr Loh Meng See.

    The Ministry may be right to chastise the Board members who should know better, but it must handle the students' emotions separately by attempting to earn their understanding through facilitative communication and persuasion. Such openness from the Ministry including a little risk taking initiative on its part will go a long way in nurturing teenagers to

Column: 360

becoming self-empowered adults. We do not learn lateral thinking by doing De Bono classes; it is by doing activities with people and learning from all.

    Sir, I agree that active citizenship encapsulates a bargain, but in any bargain, it involves two way risk-taking and resolution process being adopted by the parties in negotiation. If only one party dictates the terms, it is not a bargain; it is an authoritarian imposition. I hope Mr Simon Tay and Mr Zulkifli Baharudin will use the case of Chinese High School as their study on civil society.

    On a separate encouraging note, in my own experiences as an advocate in the community, I have been given the opportunity to persuade policy makers and be persuaded to give feedback to certain Ministries and be corrected and educated in return. I have to register my gratitude here to the Ministries of Community Development and Home Affairs for opening their doors to me and the groups which I represented in these 10 years. In our constructive engagement process, we have collaborated on many projects together. I hope all the Ministries will continue to open up more, to a broader range of people in small group meetings to gather diverse viewpoints, or even radically different ones.

    This process of engaging the people sector is clearly what I am focusing on, because in the process, we are constructing the norms and values on how to do things together and how to negotiate differences. Mr Ravindran has eloquently talked about what civil society is not, how elusive it is and the dangers ahead. It is an evolving process of definition. I do not think Mr Simon Tay or Mr Zulkifli Baharudin will find the definition. It is a collective process that we all here in this House must reach.

    I simply ask at this point for an engagement. In this engagement, we learn to give and take. We learn what can be negotiated and attempted. If no resolution can be reached, we learn how to put the matter at hand aside for further review and wait for another round of discussion,

Column: 361

always with an open mind and willingness to give the issue a fresh look. Never mind in the end whose proposals got accepted, rejected or amended - the time spent in constructive engagement is the humanising dimension of participatory democracy. If the Government only consults those people who can help it formulate policy, ie, the highly educated individuals, then it will fail to reach and feel the community. Civil servants, MPs and community leaders must do their part. And I hope all Members of Parliament will take this seriously.

    "The road map with clear pointers and markers" asked by Mr Davinder Singh cannot be established overnight. I agree with Prof. Toh See Kiat that disagreement is not division. But when there are disagreements, it is important that we keep an open mind to review the issues and reach a middle ground. Too many disagreements will lead to division. With sufficient time and opportunity given to relationship building between the Government and society, we are closer to knowing how "to take the heat" as Mr Davinder said, and identify what Singaporeans truly want which cannot be assumed to be homogenous, as Mr Sin Boon Ann cautioned. The process of engagement does help, I believe, to restore the emotional bonding that Mr Inderjit Singh hopes for, the loyalty and patriotism that Mr Kenneth Chen wishes for in Singaporeans, and the trust that Mr Zainul Abidin finds essential in a pluralistic society.

    Sir, the people have to act, not just pontificate or ponder like what Mr Iswaran said. I would quickly add that the Government too has to roll up its sleeves and act with the people. It is evidently in the interest of the Government to say "Trust me". But it has to meet the demand of the voters who yell "Show me." Between this tension, it is a whole lot of effort and sincerity that must be poured in from the State and the people sector. It is easy to shut people up with robust sanctions, but what do we get in return? Demoralisation, indifference, escapism, low voluntarism, low motivation - all the

Column: 362

attributes which kill creativity. Thick-skinnedness is a necessary trait. I agree with Mr Zulkifli Baharudin, but let us not forget that the skin gets thicker only with age and experience, not everyone gets there yet. It is up to those in authority to step back sometimes and let it be.

    Without the space to express and create, we slowly kill people's imagination. Let me quote what Albert Einstein said: "In moments of crisis, only imagination is more valuable than knowledge." Has the Government provided the people with an environment to imagine and create, to better face up to any crisis in the unpredictable times ahead, which PM just a few minutes ago warned us?

    Sir, permit me to switch gear and look at broader issues. The Government has said that developing heartware in our society is top priority. Arising from this commitment, I propose greater attention to four areas.

    (1) The need for a broader definition of success beyond just material criteria so that we can tap the diversity of talents within our people. To begin with, I would like all schools and all learning institutions to develop a wider range of curriculum components to cater to students with different intelligence and talents. The future demands a multi-disciplinary approach to problem-solving, the more flexibility there is in subject mix as well as teaching and learning methodologies, the more prepared Singapore is in producing the kind of adults who are dynamic and adaptable. I am glad to hear from the Minister for Education yesterday that his Ministry is reviewing the teaching methods and teachers' quality at the pre-school level and I am so glad to hear PM's call earlier for compulsory education up to Primary 4 level. I believe that learning challenges at the secondary, primary and pre-school levels are very important.

    (2) The need to address the social divide between those who possess the competencies and connections to make it in the knowledge-based economy and those who cannot, by increasing the

Column: 363

awareness of the "haves" regarding the needs of the "have nots". I attended a seminar organised by the AMP last weekend. They highlighted rising social problems, divorce rates, increasing family violence, increasing teenage crimes, high drug recidivism, low morale and motivation among the disadvantaged families. These are not the issues of a Malay community alone. These concern all of us as Singaporeans.

    I agree with Mr Zainul Abidin who said in his speech that we cannot take multi-culturalism for granted, and it is no longer sufficient for different ethnic groups to just co-exist. We need to enhance their mutual understanding and trust for one another, not by institutionalising one Multi-Cultural Day, but more by getting different groups to do projects and programmes together. And here, I am responding to the call to act.

    I propose a buddy programme in schools to encourage cross-cultural interaction by pairing up different ethnic groups to study together, even stay with one another for a few days. At another level, we can also think about "shadowing" programmes for schools to encourage different ethnic groups to pair up and shadow a CEO or manager at work in the public and private sectors for one week, three days, or even one day. I had volunteered our company for this programme initiated by Raffles Girls' Secondary School.

    I believe that such a programme helps to restore in our young a certain degree of realism about work, and the importance of teamwork and mutual support, all the values which are extremely important in cross-cultural relationship building. I am confident that this programme would reap positive benefits in the case of teenage boys "at the edge", whose restlessness could steer them towards deviant activities if unharnessed, but could yield productive outcome if captured and properly channelled.

Column: 364



    Sir, these are just a few examples for me to illustrate the need for new ways of motivating our teenagers and enhancing cross-cultural understanding. We cannot talk about racial harmony. We must actively work at it with good programmes.

    Third, the need to create a separate, distinct Youth 21 programme similar to the S21 programme, so that we can specifically tackle the hopes and fears of our young generation. The under-25 generation today will dominate the new millennium. If they feel bored, irrelevant and trapped in their own homeland, Singapore will be the poorer for it. If they migrate, we are in a worse shape. As PM said earlier, we are not replacing ourselves, therefore keeping every Singaporean is a priority concern.

    I propose more resources to be given to the National Youth Council and community agencies to create "youth centres", as Dr Tan Boon Wan talked about yesterday, to let them meet regularly and identify clearly what teenagers want, what we can do to meet these expectations and how we can shape their community responsibilities.

    The last is the need to look at family values and increasing gender conflicts, and restore a sense of family equilibrium that we have lost in the last few decades in our incessant search for material wealth, at both the personal and national level. In the larger perspective, families are still strong, but it serves us well to find out why the bonds are weakening, how women and men can be helped in coping with their changing roles and where the fault lines are and why 1,000 women left Singapore and married foreigners. This is a serious problem for the sons of the MPs in this House today!

    Within the discussion of the impact of a knowledge-based economy on society, what new policies can be designed to enable families, not just workers, to become "knowledge families", able to transmit the kind of information and values to the children to make them learn well and willing to serve the community with pride. I support Dr Jennifer Lee's call

Column: 365

for identifying more pro-family work policies and job redesigns to help working couples in balancing work and family responsibilities.

    Sir, I would like to end with an endorsement of the view that we need more centres of prestige to be created within our society. More functions should feature guests-of-honour who are not Ministers and MPs, but other leaders of our community in their chosen fields. I feel this effort in creating horizontal connections of influence to include not just politicians and civil servants, but credible champions in the people sector, be it in the industry, the arts, education, social services, and so forth, will add healthy diversity and new leadership to public events.

    The newspapers have said that they intend to support this by covering not just ministerial functions, but all kinds of people functions, even if no Minister is officiating. This is a good start of powering people to be on the front-line to lead and influence. May I even propose that one of the two newspapers that SPH is going to publish be called the "The Unofficial News" and contain no pronouncements from officialdom.

    Sir, we need to power the imagination, the idealism and the hopes of all Singaporeans. If the Government delivers a leadership style with the same measure of creativity and innovation which it expects of Singaporeans, we are closer to building the people power for a better millennium for Singapore.

    Mr Ong Kian Min (Pasir Ris): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in this debate.

    As a country, we have withstood the economic crisis of the past two years which was described as one of our most severe economic tests since independence and are emerging relatively unscathed in general compared to other countries in the region. Column: 367

than before. They were not unanimous in agreement. Some did not agree wholeheartedly with this observation because the crisis and the structural changes and restructuring that it brought about had impacted them adversely and in a profound manner, and they are now worse off than before. This crisis has brought about many fundamental structural changes to our economy. Certain skills that were valuable in the past are now no longer needed. Some of the old wealth has been eroded, even dissipated, while new wealth has been created. If you are not careful, this will result in a widening of the disparity between at the one end, those who are well-placed to tap into and take advantage of the new restructured economic environment and, at the other end, those who are still struggling to find their feet and whose skills no longer command the same value as they are being offered by a multitude of others who are prepared to accept lower wages.     Mr Davinder Singh (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I thank all Members who have joined in the debate. It was lively and interesting.

    This debate has been characterised by three broad themes. First, the Government's people orientation. Second, the consensus in this House about what the Government has done right and, third, the sad and disappointing recurrence of cliches from Members of the Opposition.

Many MPs spoke about the need to give people more space, while recognising that it is a two-way deal. We are agreed on certain fundamental points. Firstly, that it will take us a long, long time to settle on a consensus. We have, in a manner of speaking, moved from black and white to colour. We have moved from basics in many instances to luxuries and in terms of material needs and dignity of life, we have very little to complain about. To many Singaporeans, these policies have had and will continue to have a far greater impact on them and their families than the issue of political space.

    In the nature of the issue, people development is very much tied to our education policy. That explains the huge interest in this debate in our education system. We clearly have a good system but changes need to be made. MPs have made useful suggestions. The Minister for Education has talked about his Ministry's efforts to enhance the talent of every student, make them world-ready while rooted to Singapore. Column: 393

fashion if they and their constituents are unhappy, and more importantly, that the Government is willing to change and experiment to deal with these concerns.

    And this afternoon, we saw first-hand the impact of the pleas of some of the MPs and NMPs in relation to compulsory education. That effort has paid dividends with the Prime Minister saying that he is going to instruct the Ministry of Education to look at compulsory education.

    We have truly come a long way. We are now concerned about the definition of "success". But it is not an esoteric or philosophical discussion. At the end of the day, we must strike some practical balance between our determination to be number one in everything we do and easing out on the pressure.

How do we continue to top the charts with an increasingly aging workforce and when the shrinking group of younger workers do not consider that drive is always a virtue? If success is redefined to mean that endeavours in enterprise are matters of fashion as opposed to necessity, we will all pay an economic price, what the Americans call "a double whammy", with lower growth and the increased burden of supporting an aging society. When the poor and the weak have no justice or believe that they have no chance in the system, that system will soon unravel, maybe not in a year or two, but in time.
